text: did you know you only need one piece of
equipment to make flaky tender buttery
scones it's not a food processor or a
rolling pin or even a biscuit cutter
it's your hands I'm gonna show you how
simple it is these I'm making today are
studded with currants and caraway it's a
nod to st. Patrick's Day but they're so
delicious you're going to want to make
them all year long start with 3 cups of
flour I'm spooning and leveling because
if you just shove your cup measure into
your flour it's going to pack it down
and you're gonna have too much so this
takes a little more time but it's
important especially with baking to get
all of your measurements just right and
then use a knife to level it off this is
just an all-purpose flour so this will
be number three okay one tablespoon of
baking powder 3/4 of a teaspoon of
baking soda this is a quick bread by the
way there are many quick breads and I
always use the same standard
measurements for each cup of flour 1/4
teaspoon of baking soda and a teaspoon
of baking powder so you can use those
ratios for other quick breads as well
and salt you have to have salt half a
teaspoon of coarse salt here and this
all gets aerated and combined with a
whisk and sugar two tablespoons go in so
give this a good whisk around to aerate
and now for the butter for these you'll
need one and a half sticks of unsalted
butter make sure it's very cold right
from the fridge this is important for
when we combine it with the dry
ingredients so what I like to do is cut
planks just in half lengthwise like this
again lengthwise in the other direction
so get these into relatively uniform
cubes these are about half an inch this
goes into the flour mixture and now that
special piece of equipment I was talking
about your hands just toss the butter
pieces to evenly coat in the flour so
scoop some flour and butter into your
hands like this and then press with your
thumbs across your fingers and you'll
start creating petals of butter see that
and then get them coated in flour again
and just continue in this manner until
all of the butter is broken down into
little petals it's the cold petals of
butter coated in flour that create those
flaky tender layers now to make these
suitable for an Irish celebration
teaspoon of caraway seeds and half a cup
of currants you could use raisins if you
have those but if you do use raisins you
might want to give them a little bit of
a chop and again still using our special
equipment hands tossing that about and
for the wet butter milk one cup you'll
need for the mixture make sure it's well
shaken before you measure it out that's
very important and then just sort of
drizzle it all over the dry mixture and
use a fork another piece of special
equipment
stir it in as you drizzle to evenly
distribute it I like to take a bit of it
and just give it a gentle squeeze
between my fingers and if it holds
together like it is that tells me that
we're good to go
now you can see this mixture is still
very clumpy and crumbly but that's okay
we don't want the dough to form in the
bowl it's going to all happen right on
the sheet tray our scone mixture can go
right on to a parchment lined baking
sheet and as you can see it's still very
crumbly but that's a okay again with
your hands just gather up the mixture
and gently press it together gently
press down the mixture to about an inch
thickness and then fold it in half like
this
and gently flatten it again and we're
gonna fold one more time in the other
direction now Pat the dough down into a
seven inch diameter round again that'll
be about an inch thick now at this point
you could wrap this and chill it in the
fridge for up to 24 hours like I said
you don't even need a biscuit cutter
here cut this into 8 wedges these can
just go straight across in opposite
directions and then on the diagonal like
you're cutting a pizza these will grow
quite a bit in the oven so give them
about a half-inch distance now for the
finishing touch brush the tops with more
buttermilk
and then because I just can't resist I
also sprinkle sugar on top and I like a
generous amount here two tablespoons pop
these into a preheated 450 degree oven
for about 15 to 18 minutes until they're
risen golden-brown and making your whole
house smell amazing look at these
magnificent scones they've cooled enough
but they're still warm in the center and
you can see that they puffed beautifully
they just break apart nicely kind of
like a pull apart roll so I love to
present these on a great big board like
this for my guests
so just split it down the center onto a
plate I love this with Irish cheddar
Irish cheddar is milder and a little
fruitier than most Cheddar's so it's a
nice complement here with these sweet
biscuits and juicy pears these are cecal
but you could use any pair you like that
has a nice tender skin and for the
finishing touch a generous drizzle of
good honey excellent for a dessert after
a nice dinner or for breakfast or for
lunch or for a snack how gorgeous is
that you could eat them like a sandwich
or if you're in polite company you could
serve these with a fork happy eating
